vclaim: It says a picture of the hurricane-ravaged island of Abaco in the Bahamas.
date: stated on September 2, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: An old picture of Michael's damage was recycled for Dorian.
text: Hurricane Dorian has slowed down in the Bahamas, but misinformation on the Internet about the massive storm has not slowed down. The Facebook photo published in September 2 alleges that it shows damage to the hurricane in the Abaco Islands in the northern Bahamas. It shows a few buildings standing in the midst of piles of debris near what looks like an ocean. "Pray for the Bahamas. This is the island of Abaco. The Bahamas has a special place in my heart and wakes up to this image of destruction from Dorian is tragic. The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) We've shared over 1,500 times, and we've decided to check it out. The Polyte Fact sent a letter to the user who posted the photo to see where they got it, but we didn't answer it. On January 10, 2021, in an article on Facebook, he said that Nancy Belusi had sent a letter to the Mayor of Portland after demonstrations there "to demand that he adhere to the proven book of democratic play." The main picture of that article, taken by the photos of Getty, is identical to the one posted on Facebook. But this story was published on May 23, before Typhoon Dorian formed in the Atlantic Ocean. The title indicates that the photograph was taken on October 17, 2018, on the coast of Mexico, and no, after Hurricane Michael, a storm caused catastrophic damage in Panhandle Florida. However, early reports and images from the Bahamas and the Abaco Islands in particular indicate widespread destruction. The New York Times reported that thousands of houses had been destroyed, and early images from Associated Press showed floods and structural damage. The Facebook article is not accurate. We assess it wrong.
